questions.question: A 9-month-old boy was brought to the well-baby clinic for routine immunization. He has a weight for height less than 2 standard deviations below the median. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The child's weight for height is less than 2 standard deviations below the median, which is indicative of acute malnutrition.

questions.question: A child is brought to the OPD for regular follow-up. Which of the following anthropometric records would prompt you to suspect a diagnosis of moderate malnutrition?

options.B: Weight for height < -2 SD to > -3 SD
options.D: Weight for height +2 SD to +3 SD

questions.explanation: An anthropometric score of Weight for height < -2 to > -3 SD indicates moderate malnutrition. The indicators of undernutrition include: Anthropometric indicators of different types of malnutrition in Children: height for age - Reduced height for age = STUNTING (chronic malnutrition); Age/Height - Reduced weight for height = WASTING (acute malnutrition); Weight - Reduced weight for age = UNDERWEIGHT (both acute and chronic malnutrition).

questions.question: Which of the following is an age-independent index?
questions.explanation:
All the indices listed, namely, Kanawati and McLaren index, Jelliffe ratio, and Rao and Singh index, are age-independent indices. Age-independent indices: 
      • Kanawati and McLaren index: Mid-arm circumference/Head circumference
      • Jelliffe Ratio: Head circumference/Chest circumference
      • Rao and Singh Index: Weight (kg) × 100/height^2 (cm)
      • Dugdale Index: Weight (kg)/height^1.6 (cm)

questions.question: A child in your unit is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). According to the WHO criteria, SAM is defined best by:
questions.explanation: Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is best defined as weight for height less than median minus 3SD. Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by the WHO as any of the following: • Weight-for-length (or height) below -3 SD of the median WHO child growth standards. • Presence of bipedal edema. • Mid-upper arm circumference <11.5 cm. Once the child is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition, the doctor must assess for severe edema (+++); low appetite (failed appetite test); medical complications (severe anemia, pneumonia, diarrhea, dehydration, cerebral palsy, tuberculosis, HIV, heart disease, etc.) and one or more danger signs as per IMNCI. If any of the complications are present, the child is diagnosed with complicated SAM and is managed inpatient in the facility. If the above-mentioned signs are absent, the child is diagnosed with uncomplicated SAM and supervised management at home is given.

questions.question: You are an intern evaluating a 2-year-old girl child for malnutrition. The measurement with the WHO standard mid-upper-arm-circumference (MUAC) tape shows yellow. This reading would correspond to?
questions.explanation: The yellow colour on the new WHO standard mid-upper arm circumference of (MUAC) tape correlates to a MUAC of 11.5 to 12.5 cm. MUAC tape cut-offs: Colour - Measurement - Indication: Red < 11.5 cm - Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) - Under-nourished, Yellow - 11.5 to 12.5 cm, Green > 12.5 cm - Normal. Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) tape is used in children between 6 to 60 months. It is measured between the acromion and olecranon process and is an age-independent parameter. Alternative methods for evaluating malnutrition: Bangle Test - It has an internal diameter of 4 cms. Normally, it should not cross the elbow. QUAC stick test - It is given by the formula - Mid-upper arm circumference/Height of child. Skinfold thickness: It is an age-independent parameter. Routinely, we measure the triceps skinfold thickness. It is measured with the help of Harpenden calliper. Normal: 10 mm, Severe malnutrition: < 6 mm.

questions.question: A young child is brought to you for a general check-up. The physician is examining as shown below in the image. What would be the cut-off to label the child as malnourished?
questions.explanation: The image shows the measurement of skinfold thickness using Harpenden calipers. The cut-off to label the child as malnourished would be the triceps skinfold thickness value of less than 6 mm. This is an age-independent parameter. Alternative methods for evaluating malnutrition: Bangle Test - It has an internal diameter of 4 cms. Normally, it should not cross the elbow. QUAC stick test - It is given by the formula - mid-upper arm circumference/height of child.

questions.question: A laborer's second child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has been fed rice water (rice milk) in his diet mostly. On investigations, the child is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of a child with a swollen belly, dull face with hypoproteinemia along with a poor diet history suggests the diagnosis of kwashiorkor. Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by edema and apathy. In edematous malnutrition, the initial appearance of edema is commonly observed in the feet and lower legs, progressing into generalized edema affecting the hands, arms, and face. The skin over the swollen areas may show dark, crackled, peeling patches (flaky paint dermatosis) with pale skin underneath, making it susceptible to infections. There may be sparse and easily pluckable hair. Hepatomegaly with fatty infiltration is a common finding. Associated symptoms of misery, apathy, and loss of appetite are seen in children with edema. Other options: Option B: Marasmus is a severe form of wasting characterized by significant loss of fat and muscle tissue as the body utilizes these resources for energy. It is often triggered by acute starvation or illness in individuals with borderline nutritional status. Option C: Indian childhood cirrhosis (ICC) is a chronic liver disease that affects infants and young children. Common symptoms include jaundice, pruritus, lethargy, and hepatosplenomegaly. The disease progresses rapidly, leading to the development of cirrhosis. Option D: Kawasaki disease (KD) is a systemic inflammatory disorder with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It presents with fever, rash, conjunctivitis, and cervical lymph node enlargement.

questions.question: You are sent for active field surveillance of malnourished children to a rural district in central India. Which of the following specific findings would prompt you to make a diagnosis of marasmus?
questions.explanation: Children with marasmus have a voracious appetite, whereas children with kwashiorkor often refuse to eat. Marasmus is a calorie deficit state and kwashiorkor is a protein deficit state. The signs of low protein manifesting as hypoalbuminemia and edema are characteristically seen in kwashiorkor.

questions.question: Sheila, a widowed maid, brings her youngest child to your OPD with complaints of cough and cold. She has not been able to feed her kids after the lockdown affected her work. The image of the child is shown below. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in this case?
questions.explanation: The image shows a child with marasmus, which is not associated with apathy. Apathy is a psychomotor change seen in kwashiorkor.

questions.question: Shubham, a young infant was found to have a mid-upper arm circumference of 11cms. On examination, the child appeared stunted with loss of muscle mass and subcutaneous tissue, including the buccal pad of fat. What is the grade of marasmus in this child?
questions.explanation: Wasting of the buccal pad of fat is classified as grade 4 marasmus. Grading of marasmus (depending on wasting) Grading of kwashiorkor (depending on edema) 1. Loose skin fold in groin and axilla 2. Wasting of the thighs and buttocks 3. Wasting of the chest and back 4. Wasting of the buccal pad of fat. Grade Feature 1. Pedal edema 2. Facial edema 3. Chest and body edema 4. Ascites

questions.question: A 20-month-old child diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is receiving treatmentin your clinic. Given below are five statements regarding the treatment. Pick out the incorrectstatements.
questions.explanation: Vitamin A is not given daily in the treatment of SAM. It is given on day 1, day 2 and day 14.The general treatment involves 10 steps in 2 phases:Initial stabilization phase: It focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical conditionsand requires 2-7 days of inpatient treatment.Mnemonic: SHIELDED••Sugar deficiency(hypoglycemia)Hypothermia• Infection••ELectrolyte imbalance⚫ Dehydration• Deficiency of nutrientsRehabilitation phase: It focuses on rebuilding wasted tissue and generally takes several weeks.Steps:•Treat hypoglycemia (blood glucose level <54 mg/dl): if symptomatic, give 10% Dextrose IV at5ml/kg. Feeding should be initiated with starter F-75 (formula with 75 kcal/100 ml of feed)• Treat hypothermia (axillary <35°C or 95°F): Skin-to-skin contact with care called "kangarootechnique" or dress in warmer clothes, cover head, wrap in a warmed blanket, and provideindirect heat.• Treat dehydration: Hydrate with ReSoMal (45 mmol Na/L). It is a low-sodium rehydrationsolution for malnutrition.128•Correct electrolyte imbalance: There is a deficit of potassium and magnesium and excesssodium. Give extra potassium (3 to 4 mEq/kg/day) and magnesium (4 mEq/ kg/day) for at least 2weeks.•• Treat an infection: Starting on the first day, give broad-spectrum antibiotics to all children.•Correct micronutrient deficiencies:• Do not give iron in the stabilization phase, because excess iron leads to free radical injury. Giveiron 3 mg/kg/day once the child starts gaining weight after the stabilization phase.•Give vitamin A on day 1. Repeat on day 2 and day 14.• Folic acid 1 mg (5 mg on day 1)• Zinc (2 mg/kg/day)•Copper (0.3 mg/kg/day)• Start cautious feeding: Give 8 to 12 small feeds of F75 feeds. It is low-lactose milk thatcontains 75 kcal and 0.9 g protein per 100 mL. After 3 days, transition to F100 feeds is madewhich is called a catch-up diet. This provides 100 kcal and 2.9 g protein per 100 mL. After 1 week,calories are further increased to 150-200 kcal/kg/day and protein to 4–6 g/kg/day.•Rehabilitation: The indications of entry to this phase are reduced/minimal oedema and thereturn of appetite.Beginning of feeding.•After 3 days, the transition to energy-dense feeding• Stimulation of emotional and sensorial development• Transfer to home-based dietManagement of protein energy malnutritionStabilizationRehabilitationActivityDays 1-2Days 3-7Weeks 2-6Treat or prevent:HypoglycaemiaHypothermiaDehydrationCorrect electrolyteimbalanceTreat infectionCorrect micronutrientdeficienciesBegin feedingIncrease feeding torecover lost weight("catch-up growth")Stimulate emotionaland sensorialdevelopmentPrepare for discharge

questions.question: A 3-year-old child is brought to the hospital with complaints of multiple episodes of loose stools and progressive weight loss. She was found to have a mid-upper arm circumference of 10.5 cm. Which of the following is true regarding the management of this child?

options.B: Administer 10 mL of 50% glucose IV, if unconscious
options.C: Continue aggressive hydration, even after dehydration resolves
options.D: Use ReSoMal for rehydration 5 mL/kg every 30 min for the first 2 hours

questions.explanation: Without iron - With iron OMARROW129 Progressive weight loss and mid-upper arm circumference of <11.5 cm denote severe acute protein-energy malnutrition (PEM). When accompanied by loose stools, management includes the use of low sodium ORS for rehydration of 5 mL/kg every 30 min for the first 2 hours. Management of fluid/electrolyte status in SAM: • Do not give IV fluids unless the child is in shock. • Give ReSoMal (low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition) 5 mL/kg every 30 min for the first 2 hr orally or NG tube. • Then give 5-10 mL/kg in alternate hours for up to 10 hours. The amount depends on stool loss and eagerness to drink. Feed every other alternate hour. • Give ReSoMal after each watery stool as a prevention strategy. • Do not continue aggressive hydration even after dehydration resolves. • Treatment of hypoglycemia in malnutrition: If conscious: 10% glucose (50 mL) orally or 1 teaspoon sugar under the tongue, whichever is the quickest. • If unconscious: Immediately give sterile 10% glucose (5 mL/kg) by IV. Note: 50% glucose is never used in children as it is extremely viscous and concentrated. This could lead to injection site pain, severe thrombophlebitis, and irritation. Also, this can cause osmotic overload in a three-year-old.

questions.question: A young girl who was grossly emaciated and undernourished was started on partial parenteralnutrition together with enteral nutrition via a nasogastric tube. In the first week, whichamong the following would be the hallmark for the development of refeeding syndrome?
questions.explanation: The hallmark of refeeding syndrome is the development of severe hypophosphatemia.Refeeding syndrome is a complication of the acute nutritional rehabilitation of children who areundernourished from any cause, and it may follow overly aggressive enteral or parenteralalimentation.When excessive carbohydrates are administered, the resultant increase in serum insulin levelsmay produce the following:•Hypophosphatemia (hallmark)• Hypokalemia• HypomagnesemiaA controlled transition over 3 days from F-75 to F-100 is recommended by the WHO for treatingmalnutrition, to prevent refeeding syndrome.130
